ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned theory and practical considerations behind a variety of different structural and molecular techniques.
The course provided a useful review of basic biochemistry topics and an in-depth introduction to X-ray crystallography, cryo-electron microscopy, and optical microscopy.
I have a better understanding of Cryo-em, xray diffraction, and biophysical analysis techniques.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: While the lectures were great, I feel like the notes could be organized a little better. Going back to the notes from the beginning of the semester during the final, it was sometimes hard to follow the information. Also, the homework assignment questions could be a little less confusing.

Strengths: The basic review at the beginning of the course is useful. The units on X-ray crystallography and cryo-electron microscopy are structured well. The weekly homework assignments ensure students keep up with the material. The homework questions are similar to exam questions. The study guides for the exams are useful. 

Weaknesses: Sometimes homework questions were unclear (i.e., the wording could be confusing). There were also a couple instances in which homework questions addressed content that was not yet covered in lectures.

Strengths is the topics it covered. 
Weakness is  explaining those topics and the clarity of the questions asked in the HW and exams. I had to spend many hours online to understand something that was taught in class.
The discussion sections were also very not helpful. Nothing came out of the discussion sections and I wish we had office hours instead of just walking up to TFs after class. 
I think it can be improved by better and more structured explanation. For example, after we discussed the x-ray part of the course and then Cryo-em, we went back to half of a lecture explaining what a Fourier transform is. A very important concept in the course. So I guess I wish I had lecture 17 before lecture 9 or so. it would have made the X-ray section way easier.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, its a great introduction into structural methods.
Yes. The workload was fair and the course provided useful information.
No. I got more confused on topics I already knew something about in my undergraduate courses. Cryo-em, optical tweezers, and FRET.
